title: FirstFT: Today's top stories
text:
How well did you keep up with the news this week? Take our quiz.

Robinhood, the online brokerage at the centre of wild trading in equities this week, has raised more than $1bn from its existing investors and tapped credit lines from banks to shore up its financial position after a turbulent four days.

The developments came after Robinhood and other retail brokers restricted trading on Thursday in a number of companies whose share prices had risen sharply over the past week, provoking outrage among users and questions from US politicians.

Robinhood said it would “open up trading for some of these securities in a responsible manner” on Friday, leading to gains ahead of the open of trading for console retailer GameStop, one of the stocks at the centre of this week's volatile trading. Its shares tumbled 44 per cent on Thursday.

Many hedge funds, which have been caught out by this week's big pile-ons against negative bets, are turning to data providers that use natural language processing to scour forums such as Reddit to better anticipate these trends.

Robert Armstrong, US financial editor, puts this week's extraordinary activity on Wall Street in the context of historical “pump and dump” share selling schemes and ponders the likely regulatory backlash that will follow. (FT)

Coronavirus digest

  • The rate of the US economy's rebound from the coronavirus-fuelled downturn slowed in the fourth quarter. Gross domestic product advanced 4 per cent on an annualised basis, according to figures published on Thursday by the US commerce department.

  • Ursula von der Leyen, European Commission president, ramped up pressure on drug company AstraZeneca on Friday over supplies of vaccines to the EU. The comments to a German radio station come as the EU's vaccination plan nears crisis point.

  • Novavax's vaccine is 89 per cent effective and works against the new variants, according to data published from clinical trials in the UK and South Africa. Drugmakers are hunting for new antibodies following warnings that treatments may prove ineffective against new virus variants.

  • Dubai hospitals are feeling the strain as cases surge in the party destination and Vietnam is rushing to contain an outbreak of the more contagious Covid variant in the north of the country.

  • Brands such as Budweiser and Coca-Cola are opting out of advertising during this year's Super Bowl as the pandemic shifts attitudes over spending. (FT)

Keep up to date with the vaccine rollout with our recently launched tracker and live blog.

In the news

Exclusive: McKinsey in talks to settle opioid claims The management consultancy is in advanced discussions with several US states' attorneys-general to pay hundreds of millions of dollars to settle civil claims about its role in advising drug companies, including Purdue Pharma. (FT)

Chinese warplanes simulated attacking US carrier near Taiwan Chinese military aircraft simulated missile attacks on a nearby US aircraft carrier during an incursion into Taiwan's air defence zone three days after Joe Biden's inauguration, according to intelligence from the US and its allies. (FT)

Apple chief attacks social platforms Tim Cook launched a stinging attack on ad-based social networks such as Facebook on Thursday, arguing that such platforms were responsible for real-world violence and dehumanising consumers. New rules on the iPhone will make targeting users harder for advertisers, says our Lex column. (FT)

GM aims to end petrol and diesel sales by 2035 General Motors on Thursday became the first of the world's biggest carmakers to set a deadline for its final sales of passenger vehicles powered by internal combustion engines. (FT)

Samsung warns chip shortage could hit smartphones The world's largest memory chipmaker said a global semiconductor shortage that has hindered global carmakers could also disrupt orders for the chips used in smartphones, as manufacturers rushed to respond to the crisis. (FT)

Exclusive: SoftBank plan leaves executives with potential $1.2bn gain Four top SoftBank executives, including Rajeev Misra and Marcelo Claure, are sitting on a potential collective gain of as much as $1.2bn after receiving unusual loans from the company last year to buy its shares. (FT)

2020's worst-selling retail fund manager named California-based asset manager Franklin Templeton has been named the world's worst-selling retail fund manager for 2020 after investors pulled almost $50bn from the US group, which has suffered more than half a decade of heavy redemptions. (FT)

Hong Kongers granted UK residence The UK will formally open a new route to citizenship for up to 3m Hong Kong residents from Sunday as the Home Office revealed it had already allowed 7,000 people from the former British colony to settle ahead of the scheme's launch. (FT)

The days ahead

EU Covid vaccines The EU will propose empowering governments to block exports of vaccines, forcing pharmaceutical companies to seek authorisation before shipping jabs out of the bloc. The European Medicines Agency is also expected to reach a long-awaited decision on the approval of the Oxford/AstraZeneca vaccine. (FT)

Earnings round-up Companies reporting on Friday include Caterpillar, Charter Communications, Chevron; Colgate-Palmolive, Eli Lilly, H&M, Honeywell International, L3Harris Technologies, Roper Industries and SAP. JD Sports reports full-year results on Saturday. (FT, FENS)

Economic data US consumer spending is expected to decline for the second month after a rise in coronavirus cases. (FT, WSJ)

What else we're reading

Wall Street's new mantra: green is good To most people outside Wall Street, climate change is an existential or moral issue, not a financial one. And fiduciary duty rules in America demand that asset managers focus only on delivering customer returns. But tackling climate change offers a chance to fuel future profits. Is it a turning point?

  • As the green bandwagon accelerates, it is time to consider a linguistic rethink, writes Gillian Tett. “Olive” is a valuable middle way as no “brown” carbon-emitting company can change its colours overnight.

Revolut: bitcoin hype-merchant or bank? The fintech appears to have lost its way in the unicorn forest, writes Jemima Kelly. But if Revolut really wants to be taken seriously as a bank, it needs to start behaving like one. (FT)

How close is the light at the end of the Covid tunnel? Nearly three months after the announcement of a Covid-19 vaccine, hospitals are overwhelmed and the global death toll is climbing twice as fast as in the worst days of the first wave, writes Tim Harford. Will it ever end?

Why women are turning away from MBAs Business school applications are booming, but the gender gap persists. “The impact of Covid-19 was more severe on women as they felt they were more likely to face the risk of job loss and shoulder more responsibilities of remote education and work,” says one academic. (FT)

The world's nuclear upsurge Nine countries possess nuclear arms, while another 31 have flirted with the weapons at one time or another. But the battle to stop the world's deadliest weapon from proliferating is getting harder. (Economist)

Video of the day

Building a more sustainable food system with AI A host of new innovations using artificial intelligence are boosting our potential to create a healthier, more sustainable food system. (FT)
